item.title: NEATL Theory 1: Introducing Neuroeconomics
item.description:
I. Motivations and Goals of NEATL Theory

A Neuroeconomic Approach to Language, what I’ll call NEATL Theory, is a theory or set of ideas about the neurophysiology of volitional action, language in particular. It combines a number of ideas. Most simply, it is an attempt to model and explain the mechanics of language through the structures, concepts, and approaches of neuroeconomics, a field developed by Paul Glimcher and others. Neuroeconomics is – to start with a grossly oversimplifying gist – a framework using the structure and mechanics of “decision-making” cortical maps and their support mechanisms (most importantly meta-action maps) to manifest (and thereby explain) voluntary action of humans and animals and the (internal) structures and conditions under which it operates.
